case_name: M/s. Binani Commercial Co. Ltd. v. Ramanlal Maganlal Mehta

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 371 of 1957 before Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 371 of 1957. Appeal from the judgment

facts.text: Appeal from judgment and decree dated August 22, 1955 of Bombay High Court in Appeal No. 49 of 1955.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and decree dated August 22, 1955, of the Bombay High Court in Appeal No. 49 of 1955. B. Agarwala, J. B. Dadachanji, Ravinder

facts.text: Suit filed by Ms. Binani Commercial Co. Ltd. against Ramanlal Maganlal Mehta on Original Side of Bombay High Court.

anchor.surface_text: This appeal arises from a suit filed by M s. Binani Commercial Co. Ltd., on the Original Side of the Bombay High Court against the respondent Ramanlal Maganlal Mehta.

facts.text: Appellant sought to recover Rs. 93,053-3-0 loss or alternatively Rs. 88,229-3-0 damages for breach of contract.

anchor.surface_text: In its suit the appellant sought to recover from the respondent a sum of Rs. 93,053-3-0 which represented the loss suffered by it in the transaction in question or in the alternative damages for Rs. 88,229-3-0 for breach of the companymission agents.

facts.text: Appellant is a Limited Company carrying on business in Bombay as metal merchants, bankers and commission agents.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant is a Limited Company and it carries on business in Bombay as metal merchants, bankers and commission agents. The respondent also carries on business in Bombay under the name and style of M s. Balasinor Export and Import Co.,

facts.text: Respondent carries on business in Bombay as Ms. Balasinor Export and Import Co. and Ms. Ramanlal and Sons.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent also carries on business in Bombay under the name and style of M s. Balasinor Export and Import Co., and also as M s. Ramanlal and Sons. In January 1952 the appellant agreed to sell to the respondent 300 tons of Electrolytic Zinc

facts.text: In January 1952, appellant agreed to sell 300 tons of Electrolytic Zinc to respondent at Rs. 171 per cwt. against delivery orders for Posh Sudi 15 delivery January 12, 1952.

anchor.surface_text: In January 1952 the appellant agreed to sell to the respondent 300 tons of Electrolytic Zinc at the rate of Rs. 171 per cwt. against delivery orders issued under the regulations of the Metal Traders Association, Ltd., for Posh Sudi 15 delivery  January 12, 1952 .

facts.text: Respondent promised to pay for goods by January 21, 1952 and take delivery thereafter.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent promised to pay for the said goods by January 21, 1952 and to take delivery thereafter. The respondent paid to. the appellant several sums aggregating Rs. 1,56,000 as a deposit for the price of the said goods.

facts.text: Respondent paid several sums aggregating Rs. 1,56,000 as deposit.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent paid to. the appellant several sums aggregating Rs. 1,56,000 as a deposit for the price of the said goods. The appellant tendered the said goods to the respondent whereupon he arranged to take delivery of only 160 tons and made payments on account.

facts.text: Appellant tendered goods; respondent took delivery of 160 tons and made payments.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant tendered the said goods to the respondent whereupon he arranged to take delivery of only 160 tons and made payments on account. The appellant then tendered the balance of 140 tons to the respondent but the respondent failed and neglected to take delivery of the said balance and to pay for it.

facts.text: Respondent failed to take delivery of balance 140 tons and pay for it.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant then tendered the balance of 140 tons to the respondent but the respondent failed and neglected to take delivery of the said balance and to pay for it. As a result of the respondents default in taking delivery the appellant had to sell the balance in the falling market at Rs. 81 per cwt.,

facts.text: Appellant sold balance in falling market at Rs. 81 per cwt., resulting in loss.

anchor.surface_text: As a result of the respondents default in taking delivery the appellant had to sell the balance in the falling market at Rs. 81 per cwt., and that had resulted in the loss to the appellant. That in brief is the nature of the claim made by the appellant against the respondent.

facts.text: Respondent resisted claim alleging transaction contravened Supply and Prices of Goods Act, 1950 (70 of 1950) and cl. b of Govt notification No. 14-32/17/50 dated September 2, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: This claim was resisted by the respondent on several grounds. The principal ground urged by him, however, was that the transaction in suit for the sale of 300 tons of Electrolytic Zinc was in companymission agents. The respondent also raised other contentions on the merits without prejudice to his principal contention about the illegality of the contract.

facts.text: Suit tried by Coyajee, J. on Original Side of Bombay High Court.

anchor.surface_text: The suit was tried by Coyajee, J. on the Original Side of the Bombay High Court. The principal defence raised by the respondent was tried as a preliminary issue by the learned Judge.

facts.text: Coyajee J. held on preliminary issue that contract was valid.

anchor.surface_text: On this preliminary issue, the learned Judge held that the defence set out by the respondent was not good and not applicable to the facts and circumstances of the case. His conclusion, therefore, was that the contract was valid.

facts.text: After interlocutory judgment, Coyajee J. tried merits, found for appellant, referred to Commissioner for accounts.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Judge, after delivering this interlocutory judgment, proceeded to try the issues on the merits, and having found in favour of the appellant on the said issues he directed that the matter be referred to the Commissioner for taking accounts to ascertain the damages suffered by the appellant in the light of the directions given in the Judgment.

facts.text: Respondent appealed to Division Bench of Bombay High Court (Appeal No. 49 of 1955), which allowed appeal, held contract invalid, dismissed suit.

anchor.surface_text: Against this decision the respondent preferred an appeal and the Division Bench of the Appeal Court allowed his appeal. Before the Court of Appeal only one point was argued and that was in regard to the validity of the contract. The Court of Appeal has held, reversing the conclusion of the trial Judge, that the defence raised by the respondent was good and that the contract in question was invalid.

facts.text: Appellant obtained certificate from Bombay High Court and appealed to Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: In the result the Appeal Court has directed that the appellants suit should be dismissed with costs. The appellant then applied for and obtained a certificate from the said High Court and it is with that certificate that it has come to this Court by its present appeal

facts.text: No declaration was given by respondent to appellant before agreement.

anchor.surface_text: It is common ground that no declaration was given by the respondent to the appellant before the agreement to sell was made, and so the respondent contends that agreement to sell more than 1 ton of the non-ferrous metal in question is violative of the requirements of the notification

facts.text: Supply and Prices of Goods Act, 1950 (Act 70 of 1950) passed pursuant to Art. 249 Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: It is, therefore, necessary at the outset to refer to the material provisions of the Supply and Prices of Goods Act 70 of 1950  hereafter called the Act  and to examine very broadly its scheme and purpose. The Act has been passed in pursuance of a resolution under Art. 249 of the Constitution

facts.text: Notification issued under s.4(1)(c) on non-ferrous metals: no dealer shall sell exceeding 1 ton without declaration from buyer.

anchor.surface_text: Let us now read the notification. The notification provides No such dealer or producer shall sell any non-ferrous metals exceeding one ton unless he has obtained a declaration in writing from the buyer that the quantity proposed to be sold to him does not exceed his requirements for consumption for three months

facts.text: Judgment delivered by GAJENDRAGADKAR, J. on May 1, 1961.

anchor.surface_text: B. Agarwala, J. B. Dadachanji, Ravinder Narain and O. Mathur, for the appellant. Ajit H. Mehta and I. N. Shroff, for the respondent,. 1961. May 1. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by GAJENDRAGADKAR, J.-This appeal arises from a suit filed by M s. Binani

facts.text: Appellant counsel: B. Agarwala, J. B. Dadachanji, Ravinder Narain, O. Mathur.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal No. 49 of 1955. B. Agarwala, J. B. Dadachanji, Ravinder Narain and O. Mathur, for the appellant. Ajit H. Mehta and I. N. Shroff, for the respondent,. 1961. May 1.

facts.text: Respondent counsel: Ajit H. Mehta, I. N. Shroff.

anchor.surface_text: Ajit H. Mehta and I. N. Shroff, for the respondent,. 1961. May 1. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by GAJENDRAGADKAR, J.-This appeal arises from a suit filed by M s. Binani Commercial Co. Ltd.,

facts.text: Transaction for 300 tons exceeds 1 ton limit under notification.

anchor.surface_text: and so the respondent contends that agreement to sell more than 1 ton of the non-ferrous metal in question is violative of the requirements of the notification and as such it contravenes s. 4 1  c  read with the notification and attracts s. 5 1  c  of the Act.

Supply and Prices of Goods Act, 1950  70 of 1950  and cl. b  of the Government of India Notification No. 1 4 - 32 17 50 issued on September 2, 1950. According to the respondent the said transaction was void and illegal and therefore the appellants claim was not maintainable in law. The respondent also raised other contentions on the merits without prejudice to his principal contention about the illegality of the contract.

concepts.unlisted_label: Supply and Prices of Goods Act, 1950
concepts.unlisted_description: Act for control of prices of certain goods and supply and distribution thereof

anchor.surface_text: The Act has been passed in pursuance of a resolution under Art. 249 of the Constitution for the control of prices of certain goods and the supply and distribution thereof. Article 249 confers on Parliament the power to legislate in regard to a matter in a State List but the said power can be exercised only in national interest

concepts.interpretation: Empowers Parliament to legislate on State List matters in national interest upon resolution by Council of States

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: ellants suit should be dismissed with companyts. The appellant then applied for and obtained a certificate from the said High Court and it is with tha

anchor.surface_text: Section 2 of the Act defines goods as meaning goods to which the Act applies.

concepts.unlisted_label: Section 2, Supply and Prices of Goods Act, 1950

anchor.surface_text: Section 3 provides, inter alia, that the Act applies to the goods specified in the Schedule and to such other goods that the Central Government may by a notified order specify in that behalf.

concepts.unlisted_label: Section 3, Supply and Prices of Goods Act, 1950
concepts.unlisted_description: Specifies goods to which Act applies

anchor.surface_text: Section 4 provides thus 4.  1  The Central Government may, by noti- fied order, fix in respect of any goods-  a  the maximum price or rate which may be charged by a dealer or producer  b  the maximum quantity which may at any one time be possessed by a dealer or producer  c  the maximum quantity which may in one transaction be sold to any person.

concepts.interpretation: Fixes maximum quantity which may in one transaction be sold to any person; can prescribe conditional maxima like requiring declaration rather than fixed arithmetical quantity; s.4(2)(a) is enabling provision allowing variation by locality or class

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: ution of goods, and s. 16 companyfers power on the Central Government to authorise by general or special order any officer number below the rank of an

concepts.unlisted_label: Section 4(1)(c), Supply and Prices of Goods Act, 1950

anchor.surface_text: Section 5 imposes restriction on possession and sale by dealers and producers in cases covered by s. 4 and provides by sub-s.  1  c  that no dealer or producer shall sell or agree to sell or offer for sale to any person in any one transaction a quantity of any goods exceeding the maximum fixed under cl.  c  of sub-s.  1  of s. 4.

concepts.interpretation: Prohibits dealer/producer from selling, agreeing to sell, or offering to sell exceeding maximum fixed under s.4(1)(c); applies to agreements to sell, not just actual sales, by combined operation with s.4(1)(c) and notification

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: r deciding the narrow companytroversy between the parties it would be necessary to determine the scope and effect of the provisions of s. 4 1  c  and

concepts.unlisted_label: Section 5(1)(c), Supply and Prices of Goods Act, 1950

anchor.surface_text: Under s. 6 is imposed a general limitation of quantity which may be possessed at any one time, and the proviso to sub-s.  1  makes it clear that it does not apply to the persons specified in cls.  a  and  b  of the proviso.

concepts.unlisted_label: Section 6, Supply and Prices of Goods Act, 1950

anchor.surface_text: A duty to declare possession of excess stocks is imposed by s. 7,

concepts.unlisted_label: Section 7, Supply and Prices of Goods Act, 1950

anchor.surface_text: while s. 8 imposes an obligation to sell goods as therein specified. Failure to comply with the requirements of the said section is made an offence under the Act.

concepts.unlisted_label: Section 8, Supply and Prices of Goods Act, 1950

anchor.surface_text: Under s. 13 power is conferred on the Central Government to regulate production and distribution of goods,

concepts.unlisted_label: Section 13, Supply and Prices of Goods Act, 1950
concepts.unlisted_description: Power to regulate production and distribution

anchor.surface_text: and s. 16 confers power on the Central Government to authorise by general or special order any officer not below the rank of an inspector of police to effect search and seizure for the purpose of enforcing the provisions of this Act.

concepts.unlisted_label: Section 16, Supply and Prices of Goods Act, 1950

concepts.interpretation: Imposes ban on sale exceeding 1 ton of non-ferrous metals without buyer's declaration; fixes two ceilings - unconditional up to 1 ton, conditional beyond upon declaration for consumer/dealer requirements; validly fixes maximum under s.4(1)(c)

This contention is clearly misconceived.

concepts.interpretation: s.4(2)(a) is enabling provision, not proviso controlling s.4(1)(c); cannot read provisions to create inconsistency

issues.text: Whether the contract in suit is void because it contravenes the provisions of s.5(1)(c) in that it does not comply with the requirements of the notification issued under s.4(1)(c)

anchor.surface_text: It would be recalled that the respondents contention is that the contract in suit is void because it contravenes the provisions of s. 5 1  c  in that it does number comply with the requirements of the numberification issued under s. 4 1  c . Thus, for deciding the narrow controversy between the parties it would be necessary to determine the scope and effect of the provisions of s. 4 1  c  and the numberification issued under it and the provisions of s. 5 1  c .

issues.text: Whether the notification validly fixes the maximum quantity under s.4(1)(c) or must it be an arithmetical quantity fixed immutably

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Agarwala contends that this notification does not fix the maximum quantity because according to him the requirement of the section can be satisfied by fixing an arithmetical quantity and that too in an immutable form. The argument is that the failure to comply with the provisions of the relevant sections of the Act is made penal,

issues.text: Whether the notification is invalid because it is inconsistent with s.4(2)(a)

anchor.surface_text: Then it is urged that the notification is invalid because it is inconsistent with the provisions of s. 4 2   a . It would be noticed that s. 4 2  a  enables the Central Government to fix maximum prices or rates and maximum quantities for the same description of goods differently in different localities or for different classes of dealers or producers.

issues.text: Whether the provisions of s.5(1)(c) are attracted by contravention of the notification only in case of actual sale or also in case of agreement to sell
Whether the appellant is precluded by concession of counsel from arguing validity of the agreement to sell apart from validity of the notification

arguments.claim: Respondent precluded from disputing validity of agreement to sell due to implied term that buyer would give declaration at time of sale and own default
arguments.court_reasoning: Precluded by counsel's concession; distinction between sale and agreement to sell invalid under ss.4(1)(c) and 5

arguments.claim: The notification validly fixes maximum quantity under s.4(1)(c) by imposing two ceilings: up to 1 ton unconditionally, beyond with buyer's declaration re requirements

anchor.surface_text: Let us now read the notification. The notification provides No such dealer or producer shall sell any non-ferrous metals exceeding one ton unless he has obtained a declaration in writing from the buyer that the quantity proposed to be sold to him does not exceed his requirements for consumption for three months

holdings.text: The notification validly fixes maximum quantity under s.4(1)(c) by imposing two ceilings: unconditional up to 1 ton, conditional beyond 1 ton upon obtaining buyer's declaration.

anchor.surface_text: What does the notification provide? It provides that no dealer shall sell any non-ferrous metals exceeding 1 ton unless the other requirement of the notification is satisfied. In other words, the notification imposes in the first instance a general ban on sale of non-ferrous metals beyond 1 ton but this ban is not absolute.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Fixing immutable arithmetical quantity unrealistic given variety of goods, buyers, circumstances; s.4(2)(a) authorizes variations by class/locality.

holdings.text: The notification is valid and consistent with s.4(2)(a), which is merely an enabling provision and does not control or limit s.4(1)(c).

anchor.surface_text: Then it is urged that the notification is invalid because it is inconsistent with the provisions of s. 4 2  a . It would be noticed that s. 4 2  a  enables the Central Government to fix maximum prices or rates and maximum quantities for the same description of goods differently in different localities or for different classes of dealers or producers.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.4(2)(a) enables variation by locality/class but does not mandate it or act as proviso to s.4(1)(c); notification prescribes by reference to consumers/dealers.

holdings.text: s.5(1)(c) applies to agreements to sell (not just actual sales) exceeding maximum fixed under s.4(1)(c) via notification, by combined operation of ss.4(1)(c), notification, and s.5(1)(c).
holdings.reasoning_summary: Once maximum fixed under s.4(1)(c), s.5(1)(c) prohibits sell, agree to sell, or offer to sell exceeding it; notification wording does not limit to actual sale.

holdings.text: The contract to sell 300 tons of electrolytic zinc without prior declaration from buyer contravenes s.5(1)(c) read with s.4(1)(c) and notification, and is void.

anchor.surface_text: It would be recalled that the respondents contention is that the contract in suit is void because it contravenes the provisions of s. 5 1  c  in that it does not comply with the requirements of the notification issued under s. 4 1  c . Thus, for deciding the narrow controversy between the parties it would be necessary to determine the scope and effect of the provisions of s. 4 1  c  and the notification issued under it and the provisions of s. 5 1  c .

holdings.reasoning_summary: No declaration obtained before agreement; notification requires it for sales >1 ton; s.5(1)(c) prohibits such agreements; sub-issues on validity resolved against appellant.

holdings.text: Appellant precluded from arguing validity of agreement to sell (e.g., implied term for declaration, respondent's default) due to counsel's concession that if notification valid, defence succeeds and no case.

anchor.surface_text: In fact the Appeal Court has referred to this concession more than once in the course of its judgment and it has made it perfectly clear that on the appellants side it was expressly stated before the Court that if the point of law raised by the appellant about the invalidity of the notification failed he would be out of Court.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Counsel conceded before trial and appeal courts that notification validity determines case; cannot resile; independently, no substance as statutory scheme clear.

anchor.surface_text: In the result the Appeal Court has directed that the appellants suit should be dismissed with costs.

outcome.relief_summary: Appellant's suit dismissed because the contract for sale of 300 tons of Electrolytic Zinc was invalid, violating notification under s.4(1)(c) read with s.5(1)(c) of Supply and Prices of Goods Act, 1950

anchor.surface_text: What does the notification provide? It provides that no dealer shall sell any non-ferrous metals exceeding 1 ton unless the other requirement of the notification is satisfied. In other words, the notification imposes in the first instance a general ban on sale of non-ferrous metals beyond 1 ton but this ban is not absolute.
In the result the Appeal Court has directed that the appellants suit should be dismissed with costs.

anchor.surface_text: Then it is urged that the notification is invalid because it is inconsistent with the provisions of s. 4 2  a . It would be noticed that s. 4 2  a  enables the Central Government to fix maximum prices or rates and maximum quantities for the same description of goods differently in different localities or for different classes of dealers or producers.
In the result the Appeal Court has directed that the appellants suit should be dismissed with costs.

anchor.surface_text: It would be recalled that the respondents contention is that the contract in suit is void because it contravenes the provisions of s. 5 1  c  in that it does not comply with the requirements of the notification issued under s. 4 1  c . Thus, for deciding the narrow controversy between the parties it would be necessary to determine the scope and effect of the provisions of s. 4 1  c  and the notification issued under it and the provisions of s. 5 1  c .
In the result the Appeal Court has directed that the appellants suit should be dismissed with costs.

In the result the Appeal Court has directed that the appellants suit should be dismissed with costs.
